dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we were looking at Almaty's public transport, and, um, it sounds like their buses are seriously efficient, right? Handling like 600,000 passengers daily.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we were looking at Almaty's public transport, and, um, it sounds like their buses are seriously efficient, right? Handling like six hundred thousand passengers daily.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Public transport of Almaty is just a disastrous. Chinese buses can barely cope with the 600,000 daily passenger traffic...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally! And the LRT, after a four-year tender, that's moving along, which is good. But then you get to the metro...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally! And the L R T, after a four-year tender, that's moving along, which is good. But then you get to the metro...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? The article points out how slow that construction is. Like, two stations every five years? [interrupts] That's, uh, quite a pace compared to, say, Moscow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? The article points out how slow that construction is. Like, two stations every five years? That's, uh, quite a pace compared to, say, Moscow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Average historical tempo of Almaty Metro construction is about 2 stations every 5 years, just for comparison, Moscow will build 25 metro stations by 2024, 8-9 new stations will be commissioned annually...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Moscow's actually scaling *back* its metro construction, while Almaty is talking about this massive ring circle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Moscow's actually scaling back its metro construction, while Almaty is talking about this massive ring circle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...Moscow will build 25 metro stations by 2024, 8-9 new stations will be commissioned annually, the second large metro circle line is nearing completion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A huge ring, 50 kilometers, 28 stations â€“ sounds ambitious on paper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A huge ring, fifty kilometers, twenty eight stations - sounds ambitious on paper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The total length of Almaty metro ring will be 50 km and 28 stations...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it *is* ambitious, but, like, the article highlights some serious hurdles. They'd have to dismantle 30 km of double-track railway and, get this, demolish about 15 new metro stations on the ground.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it is ambitious, but, like, the article highlights some serious hurdles. They'd have to dismantle thirty kilometers of double-track railway and, get this, demolish about fifteen new metro stations on the ground.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To close the full metro ring circle, it will be necessary to construct a double-track railway insertion of 30 km and build about 15 new metro stations on the ground.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. That's a significant investment just in tearing stuff down. And they're planning to combine railway and metro lines? The author calls that 'poor practice.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. That's a significant investment just in tearing stuff down. And they're planning to combine railway and metro lines? The author calls that poor practice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combination of railway and metro lines is usual good practice in Europe, Japan, Russia and China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, apparently it's considered bad practice in Europe, Japan, Russia, and China. It just, uh, doesn't integrate well.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, apparently it's considered bad practice in Europe, Japan, Russia, and China. It just, uh, doesn't integrate well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combination of railway and metro lines is usual good practice in Europe, Japan, Russia and China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it could turn densely populated suburbs into 'blighted areas,' not recreation zones? That's a pretty strong condemnation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it could turn densely populated suburbs into blighted areas, not recreation zones? That's a pretty strong condemnation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such a rail circle will unite densely populated suburban districts of Almaty like Kalkaman, Terekty, Algabas, Industrial zone, Shanyrak, Burunday and Almaty-1, which become new recreation areas of the future Almaty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Plus, some of the planned expansions, like Kalkaman and Western station, aren't even happening by 2025 anymore. So the ring won't actually 'ring.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Plus, some of the planned expansions, like Kalkaman and Western station, aren't even happening by twenty twenty five anymore. So the ring won't actually ring.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the city's plans, construction of the metro stations Kalkaman and Western station next to Altyn Orda market, is going to be completed by the end of 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, Raimbek station, for instance, is just going to be isolated and not connect to the railway?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, Raimbek station, for instance, is just going to be isolated and not connect to the railway?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the eastern side of the city Raimbek metro station is already connected with railway track to Almaty-1 station...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And those plans to extend the single-track from Almaty-1 to Almaty-2? Scrapped.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And those plans to extend the single-track from Almaty-one to Almaty-two? Scrapped.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: KTZ has plans to extend single-track section from Almaty-1 to Almaty-2 with an additional double-track line insert.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is wild, considering Almaty's half-ring currently carries only 40,000 passengers a day. Moscow's much shorter ring gets 540,000!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, considering Almaty's half-ring currently carries only forty thousand passengers a day. Moscow's much shorter ring gets five hundred forty thousand!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An interesting fact, the Moscow Metro Ring Line of 12 stations, 19 km long, has traffic of 540 thousand passengers per day. Almaty half-ring metro of 9 stations, 11 km long carries in average 40 thousand passengers per day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? It just makes you wonder about the, um, the overall strategy here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? It just makes you wonder about the, um, the overall strategy here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds like there's a lot of internal friction too, between Akimat and KTZ.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds like there's a lot of internal friction too, between Akimat and K T Z.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the article suggests technical implementation is only possible with their 'close opposition and competition.' And they've downgraded existing stations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the article suggests technical implementation is only possible with their close opposition and competition. And they've downgraded existing stations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Technical implementation of metro ringing is only possible by close cooperation between Akimat and KTZ. ... After railway stations transfer of the Almaty-1 and Almaty-2 from balance of KTZ to the ownership of Almaty City, the stations were significantly modernized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, all in all, the ambitious metro ring project... seems to have a lot of, uh, red flags.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, all in all, the ambitious metro ring project... seems to have a lot of, uh, red flags.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And the author even says their opinion might not reflect the official government plans, so, you know, we'll see.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And the author even says their opinion might not reflect the official government plans, so, you know, we'll see.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Authors opinion may not reflect with official program plans of the Government and Akimat of Almaty
